quiz.question: A window in computer graphics refers to a world-coordinate area selected for display.
A viewport is the area on the display device where the window's contents are mapped.
Clipping is the process of removing parts of graphical primitives that lie outside the window.
Point clipping checks if a point's coordinates lie within the window boundaries.
In the Cohen-Sutherland algorithm, a region code of 0000 indicates that a point is completely outside the window.
The Cohen-Sutherland algorithm divides the area around the window into 8 regions.
If both endpoints of a line have the same non-zero bit in their region codes, the line is completely outside the window.
The brute force line clipping algorithm is computationally efficient for scenes with many lines.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm clips a polygon by comparing it against each window boundary one at a time.
In the Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm, when both vertices of an edge are inside the boundary, only the second vertex is saved.
The Weiler-Atherton polygon clipping algorithm can handle concave polygons without producing degenerate results.
Text clipping can be performed using an all-or-none string clipping approach.
In viewport transformation, the mapping from window to viewport coordinates is linear.
The region code in Cohen-Sutherland uses 4 bits to represent the position relative to the window.
A line that is completely inside the window will have both endpoints with region code 0000.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm can produce multiple disjoint polygons after clipping.
In the Weiler-Atherton algorithm, when following the window boundary, you always turn right at intersections.
Clipping concave polygons is generally simpler than clipping convex polygons.
The brute force clipping algorithm calculates intersection points for all lines regardless of their position relative to the window.
In the viewport transformation, if the window and viewport have different aspect ratios, the image may be distorted.
The Cohen-Sutherland algorithm requires floating-point arithmetic for intersection calculations.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm processes each polygon edge against all four window boundaries simultaneously.
All-or-none character clipping removes entire characters if any part lies outside the window.
The Weiler-Atherton algorithm is primarily used for line clipping, not polygon clipping.
A point is considered inside the clip window if its x-coordinate is greater than xwmin and less than xwmax, and similarly for y-coordinate.
The region code bit 1 in Cohen-Sutherland indicates that the point is to the right of the window.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm always outputs a convex polygon after clipping.
Clipping curves, such as circles, requires finding intersection points with the window boundary.
The viewport transformation equations preserve the relative positions of points within the window.
In Cohen-Sutherland, if the logical AND of the region codes of two endpoints is non-zero, the line is trivially accepted.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm can handle self-intersecting polygons without modification.
The Weiler-Atherton algorithm uses two polygons: the subject polygon and the clip polygon.
Text clipping at the character level is also known as all-or-none character clipping.
Clipping is only necessary for lines and polygons, not for text or curves.
The region code in Cohen-Sutherland uses the order: bit 1 = top, bit 2 = bottom, bit 3 = right, bit 4 = left.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm processes vertices in the order they appear in the polygon.
The Weiler-Atherton algorithm may produce multiple separate polygons as output after clipping a concave polygon.
In the viewport transformation, if the window is larger than the viewport, the image will be scaled down.
Cohen-Sutherland algorithm is more efficient than brute force because it avoids unnecessary intersection calculations.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm works by clipping the polygon against one boundary at a time, updating the polygon after each step.
Weiler-Atherton algorithm is suitable for clipping arbitrary polygons, including those with holes.
Clipping a point requires checking its coordinates against four inequalities.
In Cohen-Sutherland, a line that cannot be trivially accepted or rejected must be split and tested further.
The Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm always produces a single, connected polygon as output.
Weiler-Atherton algorithm uses a turn-right rule at intersections to follow either the subject polygon or the clip polygon.
All-or-none string clipping removes an entire string if any part of it lies outside the window.
The viewport transformation maps the window coordinates directly to screen pixel coordinates.
Cohen-Sutherland algorithm assigns a 4-bit code where each bit corresponds to a half-space relative to the window.
Sutherland-Hodgman algorithm can be implemented using a series of clipping passes, one for each window edge.
Weiler-Atherton algorithm requires the polygons to be simple (non-self-intersecting) to work correctly.
Clipping is performed to improve rendering performance by eliminating invisible parts of primitives.
